abstract: Editorial argues that revised No Child Left Behind Act goes too far in relaxing state accountability and federal oversight and would particularly hurt underprivileged children; holds Congress must overhaul law carefully, without retreating from core provisions that require states to do better by children in return for federal aid.
snippet: The revised No Child Left Behind law would allow states to ignore educational failure.
lead_paragraph: The revised No Child Left Behind law would allow states to ignore educational failure.

headline.main: The Wrong Fix for No Child Left Behind
